document.docAuthor: Qiu, Lu, Che, Yang-Li & Wang, Zong-Qing
document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic study of Eupolyphaga Chopard, 1929 (Blattodea: Corydiidae: Corydiinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic study of Eupolyphaga Chopard, 1929 (Blattodea: Corydiidae: Corydiinae)

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Figs. 4 A–K; 13 A–C; 17 A–D; 38 A–B, L; 39 A–C)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Polyphaga sinensis
Walker, 1868 : 14
, female holotype , “North China ”;
Chopard 1922 : 194
, “ Chine . septentrionale”.

Homoeogamia sinensis
Saussure, 1869 : 282
, 2 males , “Le Nord de la Chine , Pékin ”. Syn. nov.

Polyphaga limbata
Kirby, 1903 : 379
, new name for
Homoeogamia sinensis Saussure
;
Kirby 1904 : 172
, “N. China ”;
Chopard 1922 : 194
, “ Chine : Pékin ; montagnes au nord de Pékin ”;
Chopard 1929 : 269
, Discussion on
P. limbata
.

Eupolyphaga limbata :
Wu 1935 : 29
, “N. China ”;
Princis 1959 : 149
, discussion on
Eupolyphaga limbata
, treated
E. limbata
as a valid species and synonymized
E. thibetana
under
E. limbata
;
Princis 1962 : 54
.

of

( NHM , No. #876173), female,

sinensis
.”; “
Polyphaga sinensis Walker
”.

of

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Eupolyphaga sinensis (Walker)
: A–C. Males from Beijing; D–E. Female from Beijing; F–H.
Polyphaga sinensis Walker
, female, holotype (with labels), from north China, F–H photographed by Zong-Qing Wang, copyright the Natural History Museum, United Kingdom (NHM). I–K.
Homoeogamia sinensis Saussure
=
Heterogamia sinensis (Saussure)
, male, syntypus (with labels), from Beijing, I–K photographed by Peter Schwendinger, copyright Museum d'Histoire Naturelle, Switzerland (GMNH). Scale bar 1 cm for A–E, F–G; I–J without scale bar.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The male
E. sinensis
superficially resembles
E. shennongensis
sp. nov.
, but can be easily distinguished from the latter by the following characters: 1) legs and abdomen pale yellowish ( Fig. 4 B ), while legs and abdomen brown in
E. shennongensis
sp. nov.
( Fig. 5 D ); 2) the yellowish white margin in pronotum usually wider (Fig. 13 A–B), while narrower in
E. shennongensis
sp. nov.
(Fig. 13 D–E); 3) styli small ( Fig. 17 B ), while larger in
E. shennongensis
sp. nov.
( Fig. 18 B ). This species is also historically confused with
E. thibetana
and
E. yunnanensis
in male, but it can be distinguished from the latter two by the dense and interfered maculae on tegmina ( Fig. 4 A, C, I ), while the maculae in
E. thibetana
and
E. yunnanensis
are isolated and much more scattered ( Fig. 6 A, F, H, J, L ).

Redescription. Male. General: measurements (mm): body length: 17.7–23.4, overall length: 28.5–33.5, pronotum length×width: 4.7–6.2×8.1–10.2, tegmen length: 25.8–30.1. Size median to large, pale yellow, with brown maculae on tegmina ( Fig. 4 A–C). Head: longer than width. Vertex black. Interocular space moderate, narrower than the distance between ocelli. Ocelli large, ocelli ridge distinct, curved, pubescent. Frons wrinkled, dark brown, lateral with two dimples which next to the antennal sockets. Antennae brown. Clypeus distinct, anteclypeus yellowish white, post-clypeus yellowish brown to brown, median with a longitudinal line divides it into two parts, sometimes the two parts are occupied by two large brown spots. Labrum small, yellowish brown, distal margin white, depressed. Maxillary palpi and labial palpi brown, with joint parts yellow (Fig. 13 B–C). Pronotum: dark brown, anterior margin widely whitish yellow, subtransparent. Surface generally with small yellowish pubescence, anterior and lateral margins with additional long brown setae. Apex of anterior margin slightly convex and truncated; lateral fore margins oblique; lateral parts straight, forming an angle with the anterior margin; hind margin slightly curved (Fig. 13 A). Tegmina and wings: exceeded the end of abdomen about 10.4–14.5mm . Tegmina light brownish yellow, hyaline, densely with brown speckles, the speckles mix together, not isolated, divide the hyaline part into many small irregular spots, the brown and hyaline speckles usually evenly distributed. Wings brownish hyaline, slightly maculated, venation distinct. Legs: whitish yellow, covering with brown setae, tibial spines reddish brown. Abdomen: pale whitish yellow. Supra-anal plate in ventral view well pubescent, apex protruded; two median sclerites elongate; cerci short ( Fig. 17 A ). Subgenital plate unicolored for the exposed part, hind margin setose, nearly straight; styli small, asymmetrical, left longer than the right ( Fig. 17 B ). Genitalia: well sclerotized. Left phallomere: anterior of L1 round, with a large beak-shaped process towards left, two hind lobes stout; L2 thick, roundly curved, the right end widened; L3 robust, short, curved; pda well developed, paa gentle protruded; L8 large. Right phallomere: small. R1M hollowed; R1L well sclerotized, thick; R3 concave; R2 generally divided into two chunks, the outer one much larger than the inner one ( Fig. 17 C–D).

Female. Measurements (mm): body length: 23.4–30.2, body width: 17.8–21.5. Unicolored, in dorsal view, dark brown, pubescent, anterior margin of pronotum reddish brown; in ventral view, head dark reddish brown, legs, abdomen generally reddish brown, margins of abdomen dark brown, tibial spines black. Supra-anal plate transverse type , hind margin nearly straight, median distinctly emarginated, and divided by a longitudinal line. Subgenital plate reddish brown, with median protruded, bulged ( Fig. 4 D–G).
Nymph. Similar to the female, reddish brown to dark brown, some individuals lighter colored.

Ootheca. As Fig. 38 A–B and L. Reddish brown. Serration of keel long, strongly curved, each one’s apex reaching to the other one’s back. Respiratory canals well developed. The arrangement of longitudinal ridges compacted.

Variation. Males vary in the following characters: 1) post-clypeus with two large brown spots or not; 2) the whitish yellow margin of pronotum may expand in some individuals, which only with pronotum disc brown, the rest part all whitish yellow; 3) the speckles on the tegmina can be reduced, which with anal and R areas lack brown speckles; some individuals may also have denser maculae, the tegmina strong brownish, which only with small transparent maculae.
Natural History. Females and nymphs can be found inside the tree hole in the forest ( Fig. 39 A ), or under stones ( Fig. 39 B–C).

Distribution. China ( Beijing , Hebei , Henan , Neimenggu , Liaoning , Jilin , Tianjin , Shanxi , Shaanxi , Ningxia , Shandong , Jiangsu , Shanghai , Anhui , Chongqing , Guizhou , Yunnan ) ( Fig. 2 ); Russia .

Remarks. This species is well known as “medicine roach” in China and is very common in North China . It was originally described based on a female from North China as a member of
Polyphaga ( Walker 1868 )
. At that time, Saussure (1869) also described a species named
Homoeogamia sinensis
based on two males from Beijing . Dohrn (1888) moved
Homoeogamia sinensis Saussure
to
Heterogamia
based on a female specimen. Later, Saussure (1893) thought the female Dohrn (1888) mentioned was different from his
Homoeogamia sinensis
, he followed Dohrn (1888) to keep
Homoeogamia sinensis Saussure
in genus
Heterogamia
, and named the female of Dohrn (1888) as
Heterogamia dohrniana
. Kirby (1903) synonymized
Heterogamia dohrniana Saussure
under
Heterogamia sinensis (Saussure)
, moved
Heterogamia sinensis
to
Polyphaga
and renamed it as
Polyphaga limbata
due to the repetition of using “sinensis” as species name in the same genus. The name
Polyphaga limbata Kirby
was latter confused with
E. thibetana (Chopard)
and
E. yunnanensis (Chopard)
by several researchers due to the misidentification. After examining the type specimen of
Homoeogamia sinensis
housed in GMNH (the type labels are not written as “
Homoeogamia sinensis
”, but “
Heterogamia sinensis
”, they are probably not the original labels, but changed by Saussure himself due to the status change from
Homoeogamia sinensis
to
Heterogamia sinensis
), we found the type of
Homoeogamia sinensis
is no doubt an individual of
Eupolyphaga sinensis
, and also, we have examined a large number of specimens of
Eupolyphaga
from North China , especially in Beijing , there’s no other species but
E. sinensis
. Therefore, we confirm that
Homoeogamia sinensis
is a junior synonym of
E. sinensis
, the new name
E. limbata
for
H. sinensis
is also unavailable.
